results.title: Selling your personality [B&W]
results.brief_description: Part of a sales training series this episode shows the right and wrong methods of retail selling. It demonstrates various examples of the type of courteous and sincere customer service that results in sales and resales.

results.title: Selling out
results.brief_description: Dramatises a farmer’s last day at the ancestral home on Canada’s Prince Edward Island. Examines some of the economic and personal implications of the loss of the farmer’s home.

results.title: Selling Australia
results.creator_credit: Julia Redwood, Ed Punchard, Prospero Productions and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Selling Australia’ is a series of four documentaries exploring Australia’s cultural identity in response to the tourism industry. More deeply, the series explores the Australian cultural fabric and the dichotomies that exist within the country both culturally and politically. The Games” explores the role journalism and advertising had in encapsulating the Australian spirit in preparation for the Sydney 2000 Olympics and the response of the international media. “The Brand” looks at identities like Paul Hogan and cultural icons (the koala, Sydney Opera House and Uluru/Ayers Rock) and how they’re used to establish the brand “Australia”. In “Tourist town” the cultural and environmental impact of tourism is highlighted. Focusing on Cairns as a destination, we see how the tourist dollar has driven ecological change that sits at odds with the development of local culture and community. “The Red heart” focuses on the importance of the ‘outback in promoting the country and how Aboriginal culture has been used to sell Australia as a ‘spiritual’ destination. “Selling Australia” raises questions about the distance between the mythologised image and reality of a place and culture. Narrated by Sigrid Thornton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julia Redwood, Ed Punchard, Prospero Productions and Film Australia

results.title: Selling America. - [Ed. version]
results.creator_credit: General Motors and Jam Handy Organization
results.brief_description: A dramatisation of Benjamin Franklin’s principle of human association as applied to modern salesmanship. The following rules for successful selling are suggested: Get the prospect talking; don’t argue but be pleasant and helpful; agree with the customer, answering “yes…, but…”; don’t contradict and avoid being too positive; make the most use of time, bringing points of direct interest to the customer with other points about the product. An edited version.

results.title: Sell Yourself : Successful Job Interviewing
results.creator_credit: Kier M. Cline, Barbara Arrigo, Cinema Video Center and Learning Seed
results.brief_description: Going through a job interview is a nerve-racking experience for most of us. This video teaches you the skills needed to present yourself well and win a tough job interview. Over a dozen common interview situations are re-enacted in a dramatic and often humorous way to show you how not to proceed as well as how to impress your interviewer, from the moment you arrive to the moment the interview is closed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kier M. Cline, Barbara Arrigo, Cinema Video Center and Learning Seed

results.title: Self defence by plants
results.brief_description: A study of the various self-protective characteristics which are found among plants, including the early seed case, the bud scales and leaf hairs, and the different methods of protection used by leaves and flowers against damage by rain and animals.
results.description: A study of the various self-protective characteristics which are found among plants, including the early seed case, the bud scales and leaf hairs, and the different methods of protection used by leaves and flowers against damage by rain and animals.

results.title: Self construct
results.brief_description:
“Self Construct” explores the personal feelings of a young woman grappling with notions of self identity. The work explores complex ideas of exteranl /internal constructions of “self”. She asks the question - Where does ones identity come from?

Fontaine uses a cut up graphic style to to reflect her sense of dislocation and alienation from others.

Perceptions of memory and thought, interpretation and meaning, are all ideas explored in this innovative and thoughtful work.

“Self Construct” was awarded The Managesoft Award for “Best Final Year Interactive Project ” in the Victoria University BA multimedia course in 2001.

“Self Construct” is also a finalist in the Mayne Award for Multimedia Adelaide Festival Awards for Literature.
